The permanent polarisation is  

\[
\boxed{\;\mathbf P(r)=\frac12 P_{0}\,r\,\mathbf e _r ,\qquad 
0\le r\le a\;}
\]

where \(r\) is the cylindrical‑radius measured from the axis.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a)   Charge density

For a material with a prescribed polarisation the **bound** charge densities are  

\[
\rho_{\rm b}= -\boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot\!\mathbf P ,
\qquad   
\sigma_{\rm b}= \mathbf P\!\cdot\!\hat {\bf n},
\]

the latter being evaluated on any interface (\(\hat{\bf n}\) outward normal).

In cylindrical co‑ordinates,
\[
\boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot\!(F(r)\,\mathbf e_r)
      =\frac{1}{r}\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}r}[rF(r)],
\]
so with \(F(r)=\tfrac12P_{0}r\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot\!\mathbf P &=
\frac{1}{r}\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}r}\Bigl[r\bigl(\tfrac12P_{0}r\bigr)\Bigr]    
     =\frac{1}{r}\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}r}\Bigl(\tfrac12P_{0}r^{2}\Bigr)
     =\frac{1}{r}(P_{0}r)=P_{0}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\rho_{\rm b}= -P_{0}\quad({\rm uniform\;inside}) } .
\]

On the lateral surface \(r=a\) the outward normal is \(\hat{\bf n}= \mathbf e_r\); therefore  

\[
\boxed{\sigma_{\rm b}= \mathbf P\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf n}
        =\frac12P_{0}a }\qquad (r=a).
\]

There is no inner surface, so these two expressions completely describe the bound charge.


--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b)   Magnetic field generated when the cylinder rotates

When the whole body rotates steadily with angular velocity \(\boldsymbol\omega=\omega\mathbf e_z\),
every element of bound charge moves with the local velocity  

\[
\mathbf v =\boldsymbol\omega\times\mathbf r
          =\omega r\,\mathbf e_\varphi .
\]

Consequently the **volume** bound–charge current density is  

\[
\boxed{\mathbf J_{\rm vol}= \rho_{\rm b}\,\mathbf v
       =-\;P_{0}\,\omega r\,\mathbf e_\varphi },
\qquad 0<r<a .
\]

The surface bound charge on the mantle also circulates, providing a surface current  

\[
\boxed{\mathbf K_{\rm surf}= \sigma_{\rm b}\,\mathbf v
       =\frac12P_{0}\,a\,\omega a\,\mathbf e_\varphi
       =\frac12P_{0}\,\omega a^{2}\,\mathbf e_\varphi }
\quad\text{(at }r=a\text{)} .
\]

Because of the cylindrical symmetry the magnetic field can only have a
\(z\)-component that depends on \(r\):
\[
\mathbf B(r)=B_z(r)\,\mathbf e_z .
\]

Maxwell–Ampère’s law (static case) reads  

\[
\boldsymbol\nabla\times\mathbf B =\mu_{0}\mathbf J_{\rm tot},
\]

and for the assumed form of \(\mathbf B\)

\[
(\boldsymbol\nabla\times\mathbf B)_\varphi
    =-\frac{{\rm d}B_z}{{\rm d}r}
    =\mu_{0}J_{\varphi}(r)
    =-\mu_{0}P_{0}\omega r .
\tag{1}
\]

Equation (1) integrates to  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}B_z}{{\rm d}r}= \mu_{0}P_{0}\omega r
\Longrightarrow
B_z(r)=\frac12\mu_{0}P_{0}\omega r^{2}+C .
\tag{2}
\]

The constant \(C\) follows from the jump condition at the outer surface.
Across a surface bearing a sheet current \(\mathbf K\),

\[
\bigl[\mathbf B_{\rm out}-\mathbf B_{\rm in}\bigr]\times\hat{\bf n}
         =\mu_{0}\mathbf K .
\]

With \(\hat{\bf n}= \mathbf e_r\) (pointing outward) and noting that the field vanishes far outside the long cylinder (\(\mathbf B_{\rm out}=0\)), we obtain  

\[
-B_z(a)\,\mathbf e_z\times\mathbf e_r =\mu_{0}K_\varphi\mathbf e_\varphi
\;\Rightarrow\;
B_z(a) = -\mu_{0}K_\varphi
       = -\frac12\mu_{0}P_{0}\omega a^{2}.
\]

Putting this into Eq.(2) fixes the integration constant,

\[
C = -\frac12\mu_{0}P_{0}\omega a^{2},
\]

and finally

\[
\boxed{
B_z(r)=\mu_{0}P_{0}\omega\left(\frac{r^{2}}{2}-\frac{a^{2}}{2}\right)},
\qquad 0\le r\le a .
\]

Therefore, **on the axis** (\(r=0\))

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbf B_{\text{axis}}
   = -\,\mu_{0}\,P_{0}\,\omega\,a^{2}\;\mathbf e_{z}},
\]

i.e. the magnetic field points along the negative \(z\)-direction (opposite to the sense of rotation for \(P_{0}>0\)) with magnitude  

\[
|\mathbf B_{\text{axis}}| = \mu_{0}P_{0}\,\omega\,a^{2}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{ll}
\text{(a)}&\rho_{\rm b}=-P_{0},\qquad 
            \sigma_{\rm b}= \dfrac12P_{0}a \\[6pt]
\text{(b)}&\displaystyle 
\mathbf B_{\text{axis}} = -\mu_{0}P_{0}\,\omega\,a^{2}\,\mathbf e_{z}
\end{array}}
\]

So (a): C = 4π ε₀ b.

(b) Energy density u(r)=½ ε₀ E^2 . For r > b (outside), field magnitude E = (1/(4π ε₀))* Q/r² . Inside conductor (r<b) zero. So u(r) = (1/2)ε₀ [ (1/(4π ε₀) ) Q / r² ]^2 = (1/2) ε₀ ( Q^2 /(16 π^2 ε₀^2 r⁴ )) = Q^2 /(32 π^2 ε₀ r⁴ ). Simplify maybe as u(r)= Q^2/(32 π^2 ε₀ r^4).

Alternatively express via V or C etc but fine.

(c) Total electrostatic energy stored U = ∫ u dτ over all space outside sphere. Use spherical shells: dU = u*4π r^2 dr. Plug:

u = Q^2/(32 π^2 ε₀ r^4)

Multiply: dU = (Q^2/(32 π^2 ε₀ r^4)) * 4π r^2 dr = Q^2/(8 π ε₀) * (dr / r^2 ).

Integrate from r=b to ∞: U = Q^2/(8 π ε₀) ∫_b^{∞} dr / r^2 = Q^2/(8 π ε₀) [ -1/r ]_{b}^{∞}= Q^2/(8 π ε₀)*(1/b). So U = Q^2/(8 π ε₀ b). Using relation V = Q/(4π ε₀ b ), we can also write U = ½ Q V = (1/2)(Q)(Q/(4π ε₀ b)) = Q^2/(8π ε₀ b). Good.

Also expressed as U = (1/2)C V^2 = (1/2)(4π ε₀ b)* (Q/(4π ε₀ b))^2 = same result.

(d) Work done bringing infinitesimal dq from infinity onto already-charged sphere: W = ∫_0^Q V(q') dq' where V depends on current charge q': V = q'/(4π ε₀ b). Thus W = ∫_0^Q (q'/ (4π ε₀ b)) dq' = Q^2/(8π ε₀ b). Same as above.

(e) Now there are two concentric thin metal spheres radii a (inner) and b (outer). Potential difference V applied between them; i.e., inner sphere at higher potential perhaps. The system forms a capacitor. Electric field exists only in region a<r<b: radial E = (1/(4π ε₀)) * Q_enc / r^2 , where Q is charge on inner sphere (+Q) and opposite on outer (-Q). Let's compute expression: E_a = V / (a^2*(1/a - 1/b)) = V / ((a^2)((b-a)/ab)) = V / ( (a^2)*(b-a)/(ab) ) = V * ab / (a^2 (b-a)) = V * b / (a (b-a)). We want minimize E_a w.r.t a (with b constant, V constant). Define f(a) = b/[a(b-a)] . Minimize positive a < b.

Take derivative df/da set zero.

#### Dispersion (Fresnel) equation for the phase speed  

Equation (3) represents a homogeneous linear system for the amplitudes
\(E_{1},E_{2},E_{3}\).  Writing it as  

\[
\underbrace{\Bigl[D_{jj}\delta_{jk}+S_{j}S_{k}\Bigr]}_{\displaystyle A_{jk}}
E_{k}=0,\qquad 
D_{jj}\equiv\frac{V^{2}}{V_{j}^{2}}-1,
\]

non‑trivial solutions exist iff  

\[
\det(A)=0 .
\]

Because \(A=D+{\bf S}{\bf S}^{T}\) with \(D\) diagonal, the well‑known
matrix determinant lemma gives  

\[
\det(A)=\prod_{j=1}^{3}D_{jj}
         \Biggl[1+\sum_{j=1}^{3}\frac{S_{j}^{2}}{D_{jj}}\Biggr]=0 .
\]

\[

\tag{4}

|----------|---------------------|

|Electric field \({\bf E}\) (polar vector) | Odd: \({\bf E}'({\bf x}')=-{\bf E}({\bf x})\) |
|Magnetic field \({\bf B}\) (axial /pseudo‑vector) | Even: \({\bf B}'({\bf x}')=+{\bf B}({\bf x})\) |

A parity operation multiplies any ordinary (polar) vector by \(-1\). The magnetic field, however, is defined through the cross product of two polar vectors (e.g. \({\bf B}\propto {\bf r}\times{\bf J}\)); consequently it behaves as a **pseudovector** and does **not** acquire the extra minus sign. |----------|----------------------|

|Current density \({\bf j}= \rho{\bf v}\) | Odd (velocity reverses): \({\bf j}'({\bf x},t')=-{\bf j}({\bf x},t)\) |

\[
\boxed{\rho\text{: even},\;{\bf j}\text{: odd},\;

\[

\end{aligned}
\tag{2}

\[
\mathbf E=E_x(x,y,t)\,\hat{\mathbf x}+E_y(x,y,t)\,\hat{\mathbf y}.
\]

\[

\[

\end{aligned}}

### 1.   Image‐charge representation  

Let the dielectric constants be

  \]
  positioned at the mirror point \((0,0,-a)\),

and, **outside**, the field is reproduced by a transmitted charge  

\[
Q_{\rm tr}= \frac{2\,\varepsilon _1}{\varepsilon _1+\varepsilon _2}\,Q ,
\]
situated at the true location of the source.

If the source instead belongs to medium 2, the roles of \(\varepsilon _1\) and \(\varepsilon _2\) interchange.

---

### 2.   Fields acting on the charge \(-q\) at \((0,0,a)\)

The charge \(-q\) sits in medium 1. Two distinct contributions give the electric field at its position:

| Source                              | Effective charge felt in medium 1 | Location relative to \((-q)\) |
|-------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| Own image (induced surface charge) | \(Q_{\rm im}= \displaystyle\frac{\varepsilon _1-\varepsilon _2}{\varepsilon _1+\varepsilon _2}(-q)= -\alpha q\) | Mirror point \((0,0,-a)\)    |
| Real charge \(+q\) in medium 2      | Transmitted charge \(Q_{\rm tr}= \displaystyle\frac{2\varepsilon _1}{\varepsilon _1+\varepsilon _2}\,q = \beta q\) | Actual point \((0,0,-a)\)    |

Both lie a distance \(2a\) away along the \(z\)-axis, so the resulting field (directed upward, \(\hat {\bf z}\)) is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf E &=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0\varepsilon_1}
            \left[\frac{-\alpha q}{(2a)^2}+ \frac{\beta q}{(2a)^2}\right]\hat{\bf z}\\[4pt]
          &=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0\varepsilon_1}
            \frac{q}{4a^{2}}
            (\beta-\alpha )\hat{\bf z}.
\end{aligned}
\]

With \(\alpha=\dfrac{\varepsilon_1-\varepsilon_2}{\varepsilon_1+\varepsilon_2}\) and
\(\beta=\dfrac{2\varepsilon_1}{\varepsilon_1+\varepsilon_2}\),

\[
\beta-\alpha=
\frac{2\varepsilon_1-(\varepsilon_1-\varepsilon_2)}
     {\varepsilon_1+\varepsilon_2}=1 .
\]

Consequently,

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbf E(a)=\frac{q}{16\pi\varepsilon_0\varepsilon_1 a^{2}}\;\hat{\bf z}
\;}
\]

In the image construction the total charge appearing in space is  

\[
Q_{\text{tot}} = q+q'=q-q=0 .
\]

Since the only real charge actually present is \(q\), the remaining charge necessary to keep the total zero must be provided by the conductor. Hence the induced charge on the plane is  

\[
\boxed{Q_{\rm ind}=q'=-\,q=-2~\mu{\rm C}.}
\]

---

### (b)   Force acting on the charge \(q\)

The force exerted on the real charge by the induced charges is exactly the Coulomb force it feels from its image charge,
\[
F=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,\frac{|q\,q'|}{(2a)^2}
      =\frac{k\,q^{2}}{4a^{2}},\qquad 
k\simeq 8.99\times10^{9}\ {\rm N\,m^{2}/C^{2}},

\frac{8.99\times10^{9}(2\times10^{-6})^{2}}
     {4(0.10)^{2}}
   =\frac{8.99\times10^{9}\times4\times10^{-12}}{0.04}
   \approx 0.90\ {\rm N}.
\]

\[
\boxed{F\;\simeq\;0.90\ {\rm N}}\quad(\text{attractive})
\]

---

Moving the charge quasistatically from height \(z=a\) to \(z\to\infty\) against the attractive force requires an amount of external work equal to the increase in electrostatic potential energy:

\[
W_{\text{ext}}=\int_a^\infty F(z)\,dz

A charge moving with velocity \(v=\beta c\) emits spherical wave fronts whose radius after time \(t\) is

\Phi(z)=\frac{\tau}{2\varepsilon _0}\quad (z>0),
\qquad

\]

derivative is continuous.

\[

        =\frac{\tau}{\varepsilon _0}} .
\]

\qquad (r>a,\;r<a).
\]

\[
\Phi_\tau^{\text{ext}}(r)=0,\qquad
\Phi_\tau^{\text{int}}(r)=-\frac{\tau}{\varepsilon _0}
\quad\text{(constant inside)} .

### 1.  Green‑function for a line source situated at the interface  

Fourier–transforming in the transverse (\(x\)) coordinate,
\( \tilde{\Phi}(k,z)=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty}\!dx\,e^{-ikx}\Phi(x,z) \)
gives  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}z}\Bigl[\varepsilon(z)\frac{{\rm d}\tilde{\Phi}} {{\rm d}z}\Bigr]-\varepsilon(z) k^{2}\tilde{\Phi}=-
\lambda\,\delta(z).
\]

Solving this ordinary differential equation separately for \(z>0\) and
\(z<0\) and demanding continuity of \(\Phi\) and of the normal component
of \({\bf D}=-\varepsilon\nabla\Phi\) at \(z=0\) yields the Green’s function for a line charge **lying on** the dielectric interface :

\[
G(x,z;x',0)=\frac{1}{2\pi }\;
\frac{1}{\displaystyle\frac{\varepsilon+\varepsilon_0}{2}}\;
K_{0}\!\left(|x-x'|\sqrt{k^{2}}\right) ,
\]

where \(K_{0}\) is the modified Bessel function.  Compared with the usual
free‑space Green function  

\[
G_{\text{fs}}(R)=\frac{1}{2\pi\varepsilon_0}\ln\frac{1}{R},
\]

the presence of the dielectric replaces the factor \(1/\varepsilon_0\) by  

\[
\boxed{\frac{2}{\varepsilon+\varepsilon_0}} .
\]

Hence all potentials produced by the line charges are multiplied by the
factor  

\[
\alpha=\frac{2\varepsilon_0}{\varepsilon+\varepsilon_0}.
\tag{1}
\]

### 2.  Voltage between the two wires  

With the two wires carrying \(\pm\lambda\) the potential difference per
unit length is obtained from the Green function exactly as in the uniform
medium case,

\[
V=\alpha\,\frac{\lambda}{\pi\varepsilon_0}\,
\ln\!\frac{d}{r}+O\!\left(\frac{r}{d}\right),
\]

where \(d\) is the centre‑to‑centre spacing and \(r\ll d\) the wire radius.
(The logarithmic term is the standard result for thin parallel wires.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\lambda = C' V .
\]

\[

\frac{\lambda}{V}= \frac{1}{\alpha}\,
\underbrace{\frac{\pi\varepsilon_0}{

\]

Because the configuration is axially symmetric about the $z$‑axis, it is convenient to work in spherical coordinates $(r,\theta)$ ($\theta$ measured from the positive $z$–direction).  

---

### 1. General exterior solution  

For $r>R$, the solutions which remain finite at infinity are  

\[
\phi(r,\theta)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty}
A_\ell\Bigl(\frac{R}{r}\Bigr)^{\ell+1}P_\ell(\cos\theta),
\tag{1}
\]

with $P_\ell$ the Legendre polynomials.

At the surface $r=R$ this becomes  

\[
\phi(R,\theta)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty}A_\ell P_\ell(\cos\theta).\tag{2}
\]

---

### 2. Expansion of the prescribed surface potential  

On the sphere the potential equals  

\[
\phi(R,\theta)=
\begin{cases}
\phi_0 , & 0\le\theta\le\pi/2\;( \text{upper hemi}),\\[2pt]
0       , & \pi/2<\theta\le\pi\;( \text{lower hemi}),
\end{cases}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad   
f(\mu)=\phi_0\,H(\mu),\;\;
\mu=\cos\theta,
\]

where $H(\mu)$ is the Heaviside step function ($H=1$ for $\mu\ge0$, $0$ otherwise).  
Expanding $f(\mu)$ in Legendre polynomials,

\[
f(\mu)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty}a_\ell P_\ell(\mu),\qquad    
a_\ell=\frac{2\ell+1}{2}\int_{-1}^{1}f(\mu)P_\ell(\mu)\,d\mu .
\]

Since $f(\mu)=\phi_0$ only for $0\le\mu\le1$,

\[
a_\ell=\frac{2\ell+1}{2}\,\phi_0\int_{0}^{1}P_\ell(\mu)\,d\mu .
\]

Using  

\[
\int_{0}^{1}P_\ell(\mu)\,d\mu=
\frac{P_{\ell-1}(0)-P_{\ell+1}(0)}{2\ell+1},
\]

and the explicit forms  

\[
\begin{aligned}
&P_0(0)=1,\;P_1(0)=0,\;P_2(0)=-\tfrac12,\;P_3(0)=0,\;P_4(0)=\tfrac38 ,
\end{aligned}
\]

we obtain the first four non‑vanishing coefficients (higher ones give contributions \(\propto r^{-5}\) or smaller and may be omitted):

| \(\ell\) | \(\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}P_\ell d\mu\) | \(a_\ell\) |
|---|----------------------------------------|----------------|
| 0 | \(1\)                                   | \(\displaystyle \frac{\phi_0}{2}\) |
| 1 | \(\frac12\)                             | \(\displaystyle \frac{3\phi_0}{4}\) |
| 2 | \(0\)                                    | \(0\) |
| 3 | \(-\frac18\)                            | \(\displaystyle -\frac{7\phi_0}{16}\) |

Therefore  

\[
\phi(R,\theta)=\frac{\phi_0}{2}P_0(\cos\theta)
+\frac{3\phi_0}{4}P_1(\cos\theta)
-\frac{7\phi_0}{16}P_3(\cos\theta)+\cdots .
\tag{3}
\]

Comparing (2) with (3) identifies \(A_\ell=a_\ell\).

---

### 3. Exterior potential kept through \(1/r^{4}\)

Insert the obtained \(A_\ell\)’s into (1) and retain terms up to \((R/r)^{4}\):

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\phi(r,\theta)&=
\frac{\phi_0}{2}\,\frac{R}{r}
+\frac{3\phi_0}{4}\,\frac{R^{2}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta   \\[4pt]
&\phantom{=}-
\frac{7\phi_0}{16}\,\frac{R^{4}}{r^{4}}
\;P_{3}(\cos\theta)
+O\!\left(\frac{1}{r^{5}}\right) .
\end{aligned}}
\]

With \(P_{3}(\cos\theta)=\dfrac{5\cos^{3}\theta-3\cos\theta}{2}\),

\[
\boxed{
\phi(r,\theta)=
\frac{\phi_0 R}{2r}
+\frac{3\phi_0 R^{2}}{4r^{2}}\cos\theta
-\frac{7\phi_0 R^{4}}{32r^{4}}\bigl(5\cos^{3}\theta-3\cos\theta\bigr)
+O\!\left(\frac{1}{r^{5}}\right)} .
\]

If one prefers Cartesian form (\(\cos\theta=z/r\)), the same result reads  

\[
\phi(\mathbf r)=
\frac{\phi_0 R}{2r}
+\frac{3\phi_0 R^{2}z}{4r^{3}}
-\frac{7\phi_0 R^{4}}{32}
\left[\frac{5z^{3}}{r^{7}}-\frac{3z}{r^{5}}\right]
+O\!\left(\frac{1}{r^{5}}\right).
\]

These expressions give the electrostatic potential everywhere outside the two hemispherical conductors, accurate through the \(1/r^{4}\) term.

\mathbf v = v\;\hat {\mathbf x},
\qquad   v\ll c .
\]

The wire carries a steady current \(I\) in the \(+\hat x\) direction,
so the conventional current consists of **positively** charged ions that are
fixed in the laboratory and a stream of conduction electrons drifting
with speed  

\[
v_{d}=v\quad(\text{to the left}) .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a) Force in the laboratory frame  

Because the wire is everywhere electrically neutral, the only field present
outside the conductor is the magnetic field generated by the current.
For an infinitely long straight wire,

\[
\boxed{
\mathbf B(\rho)=\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi\rho }\;
\boldsymbol{\hat\phi}}
\tag{1}
\]

where \(\rho=\sqrt {y^{2}+z^{2}}\) is the distance from the axis and
\(\boldsymbol{\hat\phi}\) is the azimuthal unit vector round the \(x\)-axis.
At the point \((0,y,0)\;(z=0,\;\rho =y)\),

\[
\mathbf B =\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi y}\,\hat{\mathbf z}.
\]

The Lorentz force on a charge \(q=-e\) moving with velocity \(\mathbf v\)
is  

\[
\mathbf F = q\,\bigl(\mathbf v\times\mathbf B\bigr).
\]

Hence  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf v\times\mathbf B &= 
v\hat{\mathbf x}\times\Bigl(\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi y}\hat{\mathbf z}\Bigr)
      =-\frac{\mu _0 Iv}{2\pi y}\,\hat{\mathbf y},\\[2mm]
\mathbf F_{\rm lab}&=
-e\!\left[-\frac{\mu _0Iv}{2\pi y}\,\hat{\mathbf y}\right]   
     =\boxed{\displaystyle 
        \frac{\mu _0 e I v}{2\pi y}\,\hat{\mathbf y}} .
\end{aligned}
\tag{2}
\]

The force points **away** from the wire (the electron is magnetically
repelled).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b) Force in the electron’s rest frame  

Let primed quantities refer to the frame that moves with the test electron,
\(S'\) (\(\mathbf v'_{\!e}=0\)).
Relative to \(S'\) the whole wire drifts to the left with speed \(v\).

---

#### Relativistic charge‐density of the wire  

In the laboratory the line densities of the two carrier types are

\[
\lambda_{+}= \frac{I}{v},\qquad    
\lambda_{-}= -\frac{I}{v},
\tag{3}
\]

(the ions are at rest, the electrons move with \(-v\)).
These satisfy \(\lambda_{+}+\lambda_{-}=0\) (overall neutrality).

Treat the pair \((c\lambda,J_x)\) as a four‑vector.  Under a boost of speed
\(v\) along \(+x\)

\[
\lambda' =\gamma\!\left(\lambda-\frac{vJ_x}{c^{2}}\right),
\qquad     
J'_x =\gamma\!\left(J_x-\frac{v\lambda c^{2}}{} \right),
\tag{4}
\]

with \(\gamma =1/\sqrt{1-\beta ^2},\;\beta=v/c\).
Since \(\lambda=0\) and \(J_x=I\) in the lab,

\[
\boxed{\lambda' = -\,\gamma\,\frac{v I}{c^{2}}}<0 .
\tag{5}
\]

Thus the moving wire looks **negatively** charged in the electron’s rest
frame.

---

#### Electric field seen in \(S'\)

An infinite line charge \(\lambda'\) produces a radial electric field

\[
\mathbf E' =\frac{\lambda'}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}y}\,\hat{\mathbf y}.
\tag{6}
\]

Using (5) and \(\mu_{0}\varepsilon_{0}c^{2}=1\),

\[
\mathbf E'
    =-\frac{\gamma\,\mu_{0} I v}{2\pi y}\,\hat{\mathbf y}.
\tag{7}
\]

(The field points toward the wire because \(\lambda'<0\).)

---

#### Total force on the stationary electron  

The electron is at rest in \(S'\); therefore the magnetic part of the
Lorentz force vanishes.  Its entire force comes from the electric field:

\[
\boxed{
\mathbf F' = q\mathbf E' =
          \frac{\mu_{0} e I v}{2\pi y}\,\gamma\;\hat{\mathbf y}}
\tag{8}
\]

which is **still directed away from the wire**, but its magnitude is larger
by the usual Lorentz factor \(\gamma\) compared with the laboratory result.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c) Comparison and discussion  

| Frame                | Field(s) responsible for the force | Force magnitude |
|----------------------|------------------------------------|-----------------|
| Laboratory           | Pure magnetic \(\mathbf B\)         | \(F_{\rm lab}= \dfrac{\mu_{0}eIv}{2\pi y}\) |
| Electron’s rest      | Pure electric \(\mathbf E'\) (wire appears negatively charged) | \(F' = \gamma\,F_{\rm lab}\) |

Both observers agree on the **direction** (away from the wire);
what they attribute the force to is different:
* In the lab the wire is neutral ⇒ no electric field, the force is magnetic.
* In the electron’s rest frame the moving wire suffers Lorentz‑contraction of
its constituent charge distributions, acquiring a net negative line charge,
hence an electric field does all the work.

The increase by the factor \(\gamma\) is exactly what special relativity predicts
for the transformation of a transverse force:

\[
F_\perp' = \gamma\,F_\perp .
\]

---

#### What if we look from a frame moving at \(v' = v/2\)?

Such a frame is halfway between the laboratory and the electron’s rest
frames.  The wire now moves left with speed \(v/2\); consequently it possesses
both a **non‑zero net charge density**
\[
\lambda'' = -\gamma_{v/2}\,\frac{(v/2) I}{c^{2}},
\qquad \gamma_{v/2}= \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(v/2c)^2}},
\]
producing an electric field, **and** a residual current
that generates a magnetic field.  The test electron (now moving rightward
with speed \(v/2\)) feels

\[
\mathbf F'' = q\bigl(\mathbf E'' + \mathbf v''\times\mathbf B''\bigr) .
\]

Carrying through the Lorentz‑transformations one finds

\[
|\mathbf F''| = \gamma_{v/2}\,(1-\tfrac12\beta^{2})\,
                 |\mathbf F_{\rm lab}| ,
\qquad \beta = v/c .
\]

Thus the magnitude lies **between** the two limiting cases:
larger than the pure‑magnetic laboratory force but smaller than the fully
co‑moving (\(\gamma\))-enhanced electric force.  Qualitatively, the force
gradually switches its character from mainly magnetic (lab) to mainly
electric (electron’s rest frame) as the observer’s velocity approaches the
electron’s velocity.

\text{Electron frame : }

The sphere is taken to be perfectly conducting – therefore the electrostatic
field vanishes inside the metal while all excess charge resides on its outer
surface.**

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a)   Static electric‑ and magnetic–fields  

| quantity | value |
|----------|-------|
|Surface charge density| \(\displaystyle\sigma=\frac{Q}{4\pi R^{2}}\) |
|Electrostatic field (outside)| \(\displaystyle {\bf E}_{\rm out}(r)=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\,\frac{Q}{r^{2}}\;\hat{\bf r}\qquad (r>R)\) |
|Electrostatic field (inside) |\({\bf E}=0\) (perfect conductor) |

Because the magnetisation is uniform,
\[
{\bf M}=M\,\hat{\bf z},
\]
there is **no bulk bound current**
\( {\bf J}_b=\boldsymbol\nabla\times{\bf M}=0\);   
the whole magnetisation appears as a **surface bound current**

\[
{\bf K}_b={\bf M}\times\hat{\bf n}
          =M\sin\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\phi},\qquad 
      (\hat{\bf n}=\hat{\bf r}) .
\]

The associated magnetic dipole moment is  

\[
{\bf m}= \int_{\text{sphere}}{\bf M}\,dV=
        \frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}M\,\hat{\bf z}.
\]

Consequently the magnetic induction is the familiar dipole field :

*Inside the sphere* ( \(r<R\) )
\[
{\bf B}_{\rm in}= \frac{2}{3}\,\mu_{0}{\bf M}
                =\frac{2\mu_{0}}{3}M\,\hat{\bf z},
\tag{1}
\]

*Outside the sphere* ( \(r>R\) )
\[
{\bf B}_{\rm out}(r)
    =\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi r^{3}}
     \Bigl[\,3({\bf m}\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf r})\hat{\bf r}-{\bf m}\Bigr] ,
\tag{2}
\]
i.e. the ordinary field of a point magnetic dipole placed at the centre.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Demagnetising the sphere  

Let the magnetisation be reduced **uniformly and quasistatically**,  
\(M=M(t)\) with \(M(-\infty)=M_{0}\) and \(M(+\infty)=0\).
The corresponding dipole moment is   

\[
{\bf m}(t)=\frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}M(t)\,\hat{\bf z},
\qquad\dot{{\bf m}}(t)=\frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}\dot{M}(t)\,\hat{\bf z}.     
\]

---

#### Induced electric field  

In the Coulomb gauge the scalar potential remains the static one produced by
the charge \(Q\); the entire inductive effect comes from the time‑dependence of
the vector potential of the dipole,

\[
{\bf A}({\bf r},t)=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\;
                    \frac{{\bf m}(t)\times\hat{\bf r}}{r^{2}},
\qquad
A_\varphi(r,\theta,t)=\frac{\mu_{0}m(t)}{4\pi}\,
                     \frac{\sin\theta}{r^{2}} .
\]

Faraday’s law then gives  

\[
{\bf E}_{\rm ind}= -\frac{\partial{\bf A}}{\partial t},
\qquad
E_\varphi(r,\theta,t)=-
       \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\,
       \frac{\sin\theta}{r^{2}}\,
       \dot{m}(t)
     =-\frac{\mu_{0}R^{3}}{3}\,
       \dot{M}(t)\,
       \frac{\sin\theta}{r^{2}} .
\tag{3}
\]

Equation (3) holds everywhere (both inside and outside the sphere) because the
inductive field depends only on the time derivative of the dipole moment.


---  

#### Torque exerted on the sphere  

The bound surface current experiences the induced electric field.  
If a surface element carries a current \({\bf K}_b\) the elementary mechanical
force density is \({\bf f}= {\bf K}_b\times{\bf B}+ \rho_{\rm s}{\bf E}\);
here the only relevant piece is the **electric‐force on the moving bound
charges**:
\[
d{\bf F}= ({\bf K}_b\cdot d\ell)\,{\bf E}_{\rm ind},
\qquad
d{\bf \tau}= {\bf r}\times d{\bf F}.
\]

Using \({\bf K}_b=M\sin\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\phi}\) and the azimuthal form
of \({\bf E}_{\rm ind}\),

\[
d\tau_z =
   r\sin\theta\;(K_b\,dl)\;E_\varphi
   = R\sin\theta\,(M\sin\theta\,Rd\phi)\,
     \bigl[-\frac{\mu_{0}R^{3}}{3}\dot{M}\frac{\sin\theta}{R^{2}}\bigr].
\]

Integrating over the whole spherical surface (\(0\le\theta\le\pi\),
\(0\le\phi<2\pi\))

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\tau_z(t)= -\frac{2\pi}{3}\,\mu_{0}R^{5}\,M(t)\,\dot{M}(t)}
\tag{4}
\]

(the minus sign shows that the torque opposes the original magnetisation).


---  

#### Total angular momentum given to the body  

The mechanical angular momentum acquired by the sphere is obtained by integrating
the torque over the whole demagnetisation interval:

\[
\Delta L_z =\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\tau_z(t)\,dt
           =-\frac{2\pi}{3}\mu_{0}R^{5}
             \int_{M_0}^{0} M\,dM
           =\frac{\pi}{3}\mu_{0}R^{5}M_{0}^{2}.
\tag{5}
\]

It is convenient to express the result in terms of the **initial magnetic
dipole moment** \(m_{0}= \frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}M_{0}\):

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\Delta L_z =\frac{2}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,Q\,R^{3}M_{0}
            =\frac{2}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,Q\,m_{0}}
\tag{6}
\]

(The two forms are equivalent because \(m_{0}= \frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}M_{0}\).)
The angular momentum is directed **along the original magnetisation axis**
(\(+\hat{\mathbf z}\)).  


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Origin of the angular momentum  

While the sphere was magnetised it possessed an **electromagnetic field
angular momentum**  

\[
{\bf L}_{\rm em}
   =\varepsilon_{0}\int {\bf r}\times({\bf E}\times{\bf B})\,d^{3}r
   =\frac{2}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,Q\,R^{3}M_{0}\,\hat{\bf z},
\]

exactly equal to the amount found in Eq.(6).  
When the magnetisation is turned off the magnetic field disappears, hence the
field angular momentum goes to zero. Conservation of total angular momentum
requires that the lost field angular momentum be transferred mechanically to
the material body.  The transfer occurs through the **torque generated by the
induced electric field acting on the bound surface current** (Eq.​ 4).  

Therefore the angular momentum delivered to the sphere originates entirely
from the **electromagnetic angular momentum originally stored in the combined
Coulomb field of the charge \(Q\) and the dipolar magnetic field of the
magnetised sphere**.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\begin{aligned}
&{\bf E}_{\rm out}= \frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}r^{2}}\hat{\bf r},
&&{\bf B}_{\rm in}= \frac{2\mu_{0}}{3}M\hat{\bf z},\\[4pt]
&{\bf B}_{\rm out}= \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi r^{3}}
   \left[3(M\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf r})\hat{\bf r}-M\right], \\[6pt]
&E_{\varphi}(r,\theta,t)= -

&\tau_{z}(t)= -\frac{2\pi}{3}\,\mu_{0}R^{5}\,M(t)\,\dot{M}(t),\\[4pt]
&\Delta L_{z}= \frac{2}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,Q\,R^{3}M_{0}
               =\frac{2}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,Q\,m_{0}.
\end{aligned}}
\] 

The last equality makes explicit that the angular momentum supplied to the
solid comes from the loss of the electromagnetic field angular momentum
originally present when the sphere carried both charge \(Q\) and magnetisation
\({\bf M}\).

                       \bigl[n_{1}\cos\theta _I-\beta\bigr]},
\qquad       
\boxed{\;
\sin\theta '_I=
          \frac{n_{1}\sin\theta _I}
                {\gamma\bigl(1-\beta n_{1}\cos\theta _I\bigr)},\qquad
\cos\theta '_I=
          \frac{n_{1}\cos\theta _I-\beta }
                {1-\beta n_{1}\cos\theta _I}\;}
\tag{2}
\]

(the last pair are the familiar relativistic‐aberration formulas specialised
to a medium whose phase velocity is \(c/n_{1}\)).



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  Angles in the co‑moving frame  

* **Reflected wave:**  In the rest frame the interface is stationary, therefore
  the law of specular reflection holds,

\[
\theta '_R=\theta '_I .
\tag{3}
\]

* **Transmitted wave:**  Phase‑matching requires equality of the tangential
  component of the wave‑vector, i.e. \(k'_y=k'_{T,y}\).  Together with the
  dispersion relation \(|{\bf k}'|=n_{2}\omega '/c\) we obtain the usual
  Snell law written with the primed angles,

\[
\boxed{n_{1}\sin\theta '_I=n_{2}\sin\theta '_T } ,
\qquad    
\theta '_T\in[0,\pi/2]\; .
\tag{4}
\]

With Eq.(2) inserted, the transmitted sine explicitly reads  

\[
\boxed{
\sin\theta '_T=
\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}\,
\frac{\sin\theta _I}
     {\gamma\bigl(1-\beta n_{1}\cos\theta _I\bigr)}} .
\tag{5}
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  Back‑transformation to the laboratory frame  

Relativistic aberration relates a primed angle \(\vartheta '\) to the
corresponding laboratory angle \(\vartheta\):

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\sin\vartheta &=
   \frac{\sin\vartheta '}{\gamma\bigl(\cos\vartheta '+\beta\bigr)},
\\[4pt]
\cos\vartheta &=
   \frac{\cos\vartheta '+\beta}{1+\beta\cos\vartheta '} .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{6}
\]

Applying (6) to the three cases listed above gives the required laboratory
angles.

---

#### Reflected angle  

Using \(\vartheta '= \theta '_I\) and the inverse of (2) one obtains a very
compact result

\[
\boxed{
\theta _R=
\arctan\!\Bigg(
           \frac{\sin\theta _I}
                {\gamma\bigl(\cos\theta _I-\beta\bigr)}
         \Bigg) } .
\tag{7}
\]

Note that \(\theta _R\neq\theta _I\) unless \(\beta=0\); the motion destroys
exact specularity in the laboratory frame.

---

#### Transmitted angle  

First evaluate \(\sin\theta '_T\) from (5) and insert it into (6).  Writing
\(s\equiv\sin\theta _I,\;c\equiv\cos\theta _I\) for brevity, the transmitted
angle obeys  

\[
\boxed{
\theta _T=
\arctan\!\Bigg(
   \frac{ \displaystyle
            \frac{n_{1}s}
                 {\gamma\bigl(1-\beta n_{1}c\bigr)} }
        { \displaystyle
          \gamma\Bigl[
              \sqrt{1-
                     \Bigl(\frac{n_{1}s}
                           {\gamma\bigl(1-\beta n_{1}c\bigr)n_{2}}\Bigr)^{\!2}}
             \;+\;\beta\Bigr]}
   \Bigg) } .
\tag{8}
\]

Equivalently, one may write the implicit “relativistic Snell law”

\[
\boxed{
\frac{n_{2}\,\sin\theta _T-\beta}
     {\sqrt{1-(\beta-n_{2}\sin\theta _T)^{2}}}
   =
   \frac{n_{1}\,\sin\theta _I-\beta}
        {\sqrt{1-(\beta-n_{1}\sin\theta _I)^{2}}}},
\tag{9}
\]

which reduces to the ordinary Snell law when \(\beta\rightarrow0\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  Reflection and transmission coefficients for p‑polarisation  

All electromagnetic boundary conditions are most conveniently imposed in the
frame where the interface is at rest.  Hence we first compute the **standard**
(polarised‑in‑the‑incidence‑plane) Fresnel coefficients in the co‑moving
frame:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
r_{p}^{\prime}&=
\frac{n_{2}\cos\theta '_I-n_{1}\cos\theta '_T}
     {n_{2}\cos\theta '_I+n_{1}\cos\theta '_T},
\\[4pt]
t_{p}^{\prime}&=
\frac{2\,n_{2}\cos\theta '_I}
     {n_{2}\cos\theta '_I+n_{1}\cos\theta '_T}.
\end{aligned}}
\tag{10}
\]

(The cosine of the transmitted angle follows from (4):
\(\cos\theta '_T=\sqrt{1-(n_{1}/n_{2})^{2}\sin^{2}\theta '_I}\).)

-------------------------------------------------------------

#### Field‑amplitude conversion to the laboratory frame  

Under a boost parallel to the interface the electric‑field component lying in
the plane of incidence mixes with the magnetic field according to  

\[
E_{\parallel}= \gamma\bigl(E'_{\parallel}+ \beta c B'_{z}\bigr),\qquad
H_{z}= \gamma\bigl(H'_{z}+ \beta E'_{\parallel}/c\bigr).
\]

Carrying out the algebra (see e.g. J.D. Jackson, *Classical Electrodynamics*
§11.12) shows that the **ratio** of reflected to incident electric‑field
amplitudes measured in the laboratory is *identical* to the ratio evaluated
in the co‑moving frame:

\[
\boxed{ \; r_{p}=r_{p}^{\prime}\;} .
\tag{11}
\]

Consequently the intensity (power‑flux) reflectivity is

\[
\boxed{ R_{p}=|r_{p}|^{2} } .
\tag{12}
\]

The transmitted amplitude does acquire a kinematic factor because the Poynting
vector transforms.  Introducing the **apparent wave impedance** felt in the
laboratory,

\[
\boxed{
Z_{j}^{\rm(lab)}=
\frac{\mu_{0}c}{n_{j}}\;
\gamma\bigl(1-\beta n_{j}\cos\theta _j\bigr)},
\qquad j=1,2,
\tag{13}
\]

one finds the transmission coefficient for the energy flux

\[
\boxed{
T_{p}= \frac{{\rm Re}(Z_{2}^{\rm(lab})\cos\theta _T )}
            {{\rm Re}(Z_{1}^{\rm(lab})\cos\theta _I )}
        \;|t_{p}|^{2}
      =\frac{n_{2}\cos\theta _T}
            {n_{1}\cos\theta _I}
        \frac{1-\beta n_{2}\cos\theta _T}
             {1-\beta n_{1}\cos\theta _I}
        \;|t_{p}^{\prime}|^{2} } .
\tag{14}
\]

The conduction‑electron gas can be described by the lossless Drude model.  
For a monochromatic field  

\[

m\frac{{\rm d}{\bf v}}{{\rm d}t}= -e{\bf E}.

\[
-i\omega m{\bf v}= -e{\bf E}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
{\bf v}= \frac{e}{m}\,\frac{{\bf E}}{i\omega } .
\]

\[
{\bf J}= -ne\,{\bf v}= \frac{ne^{2}}{m}\,\frac{{\bf E}}{-i\omega }
          = i\frac{ne^{2}}{m\omega }\;{\bf E},
\]
so that the complex conductivity is  

\[
\sigma (\omega)= i\frac{ne^{2}}{m\omega } .
\]

Because \({\bf J}= \partial{\bf P}/\partial t\), the electric polarisation satisfies  

\[
-i\omega {\bf P}= {\bf J}\quad\Rightarrow\quad   
{\bf P}= \frac{ne^{2}}{m\omega ^2}{\bf E}.
\]

\[
{\bf D}= \varepsilon_{0}{\bf E}+{\bf P}

\qquad 
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\omega _p=\sqrt{\frac{ne^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0}m}}
}
\tag{plasma frequency}
\]

\[
\varepsilon(\omega)=\varepsilon_{0}\left(1-\frac{\omega _p^{2}}{\omega ^2}\right).

### (a) Dispersion relation

From Maxwell’s curl–curl equation for a source‑free region,

\[
\nabla\times\nabla\times{\bf E}=-
\mu_{0}\frac{\partial^{2}{\bf D}}{\partial t^{2}},
\]

\[
k^{2}{\bf E}= \omega ^2\mu_{0}\varepsilon(\omega){\bf E}.
\]

\[

\qquad c=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0}\varepsilon_{0}}},

### 2. Stability – second–order expansion  

Write a small displacement along the \(x\)‑axis:

Since the curvature of the potential is negative in every Cartesian direction,

For any harmonic electric‑dipole moment  

\[
\mathbf p(t)=\Re\!\bigl[\tilde {\mathbf p}\,e^{-i\omega t}\bigr] ,
\qquad   
\tilde{\mathbf p}=p_{0}\,\hat{\mathbf u},
\]

the far–zone (\(kr\gg 1\)) electromagnetic fields are  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf E(\mathbf r,t)&=
\frac{k^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}\,
\frac{{\bf n}\times({\bf n}\times\tilde{\mathbf p})
      }{r}\;
        \cos\!\Bigl[\omega\!\left(t-\frac{r}{c}\right)\Bigr],\\[2mm]
\mathbf B(\mathbf r,t)&=\frac{1}{c}\,{\bf n}\times\mathbf E .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{1}
\]

Here \(k=\omega/c\) and \({\bf n}={\bf r}/r=(\sin\theta\cos\phi,
\sin\theta\sin\phi,\cos\theta)\).

The rotating dipole may be written as the superposition of two orthogonal
harmonic dipoles,

\[
\mathbf p(t)=p_{0}\cos\omega t\,\hat{\mathbf x}
            +p_{0}\sin\omega t\,\hat{\mathbf y}.
\]

Applying Eq.(1) to each component and adding the results gives

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf E(\mathbf r,t)
&=\frac{\mu_{0}\,\omega^{2}p_{0}}{4\pi r}
   \Bigl\{\big[(\mathbf n\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf x})\mathbf n-
               \hat{\mathbf x}\big]\cos\!\Omega
          +\big[(\mathbf n\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf y})\mathbf n-
                \hat{\mathbf y}\big]\sin\!\Omega\Bigr\}, \\[2mm]
\mathbf B(\mathbf r,t)&=\frac{1}{c}\,\mathbf n\times\mathbf E,
\end{aligned}}
\tag{2}
\]

with the retarded phase  
\(\displaystyle\Omega\equiv\omega\!\left(t-\frac{r}{c}\right).\)

---

### Time‑average Poynting vector

In the radiation zone \(\mathbf S=\dfrac{1}{\mu_{0}}\mathbf E\times\mathbf B\).
Because \(|\mathbf B|=|\mathbf E|/c\),

\[
\langle\mathbf S\rangle
    =\frac{c}{2\mu_{0}}\;\langle |\mathbf E|^{2}\rangle\;\mathbf n .
\]

From (2),

\[
\langle |\mathbf E|^{2}\rangle
     =\Bigl(\frac{\mu_{0}\omega^{2}p_{0}}{4\pi r}\Bigr)^{2}
       \bigl[\,(1-(\mathbf n\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf x})^{2})
              +(1-(\mathbf n\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf y})^{2})\bigr]/2 .
\]

Since \((\mathbf n\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf x})^{2}+(\mathbf n\!\cdot\!
\hat{\mathbf y})^{2}= \sin ^{2}\! \theta\),
the bracket reduces to \(\sin^{2}\theta\); thus

\[
\boxed{
\langle\mathbf S\rangle =
\frac{\mu_{0}\,\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}}{16\pi^{2}c\,r^{2}}\,
\sin^{2}\theta\;\mathbf n } .
\tag{3}
\]

Equation (3) shows that the instantaneous energy flow points radially
outward and its magnitude varies only with the polar angle \(\theta\).

---

### Angular intensity and total radiated power

The **intensity per unit solid angle** (power crossing a distant sphere per
\(d\Omega\)) follows directly from (3):

\[
\boxed{
\frac{dP}{d\Omega}=r^{2}\langle S\rangle_{\rm rad}
                 =\frac{\mu_{0}\,\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}}{16\pi^{2}c}\,
                   \sin^{2}\theta } .
\tag{4}
\]

*Angular plot.* \(dP/d\Omega\propto\sin^{2}\theta\):
zero on the rotation axis (\(\theta=0,\pi\)), maximum in the
equatorial plane (\(\theta=\pi/2\)).  It is axially symmetric – the figure
is a “donut’’ shape centred on the \(z\)-axis.

Integrating (4) over all directions,

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{0}^{2\pi}\!\!d\phi\int_{0}^{\pi}\!d\theta\,
      \frac{\mu_{0}\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}}{16\pi^{2}c}
      \sin^{2}\theta\sin\theta                         \\
  &=\frac{\mu_{0}\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}}{16\pi^{2}c}
     \;(2\pi)\!\int_{0}^{\pi}\!\sin^{3}\theta\,d\theta     
   =\frac{\mu_{0}\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}}{16\pi^{2}c}
     \;(2\pi)\!\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)                  \\
  &\boxed{ \displaystyle
           P =\frac{\mu_{0}\,\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}}{6\pi c} } .
\end{aligned}
\tag{5}
\]

*Why does the power appear to obey superposition?*

Power density involves the square of the total field:
\(|\mathbf E_{x}+\mathbf E_{y}|^{2}=|\mathbf E_{x}|^{2}+|\mathbf E_{y}|^{2}
+2\mathbf E_{x}\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_{y}\).
The cross term contains factors \(\cos\Omega\,\sin\Omega\);
its time average over a full cycle vanishes,
\(\langle\cos\Omega\,\sin\Omega\rangle=0\).
Consequently the **time‑averaged** radiated power is simply the sum of the

Each contributes the usual dipole value
\(P_{\text{lin}}=\mu_{0}\omega^{4}p_{0}^{2}/(12\pi c)\);
hence the rotating dipole radiates exactly twice as much, Eq.(5).

This result is physically sensible: a charge moving on a circle possesses
both an \(x\)‑and a \(y\)‑oscillatory acceleration, therefore it radiates as if
two independent linear dipoles were present, and the total emission is the
sum of their separate emissions.

assistantfinalThe electric potential \(U(\mathbf r)\) inside the hollow dodecahedral “cage’’ obeys Laplace’s equation  

\[
\nabla^{2} U =0 ,\qquad 
U=0\;\text{on eleven faces},\qquad   
U=V\;\text{on the remaining face}.
\]

Because the governing equation is linear, the potential at any interior point is a **harmonic‑measure** – i.e. it is the probability that a Brownian particle started at that point will first hit the prescribed face.  
For a point situated at the geometric centre of a convex polyhedron, the harmonic measure of a particular face is simply the fraction of the total solid angle \(4\pi\) occupied by that face as viewed from the centre:

\[
U_{\text{centre}} = V\,\frac{\Omega_{\text{face}}}{4\pi},
\tag{1}
\]
where \(\Omega_{\text{face}}\) denotes the solid angle subtended by the face at the centre.

---

### 1.   Solid angle of a regular pentagonal face

Let \(R\) be the radius of the circumscribing sphere of the dodecahedron,
and let \(a\) be the edge length.  
From elementary geometry of the regular dodecahedron,

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\text{distance from centre to a face (the in‑radius)} && r=\frac{a}{2}\sqrt{3}\,\phi^{-1}= \frac{R}{\sqrt{3}},\\[2mm]
&\text{circum‑radius of a pentagonal face}& &\rho = R\sin\alpha ,
\end{aligned}
\]

with \(\phi=(1+\sqrt5)/2\) the golden ratio and \(\alpha\) the half–apex angle satisfying  

\[
\cos\alpha = \frac{r}{R}= \frac{1}{\sqrt3 } .
\]

Consequently \(\alpha = \arccos(1/\sqrt3 )\).

When a planar figure lies at a fixed perpendicular distance \(r\) from the observation point, its solid angle is obtained from the projected area on the unit sphere:

\[
\Omega_{\text{pentagon}}
      = \int_{\text{face}} \frac{r}{|\mathbf{x}|^{3}}\,\mathrm dA
      = 2\pi\bigl(1-\cos\alpha\bigr).
\]

Using \(\cos\alpha = 1/\sqrt3\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\Omega_{\text{pentagon}} = 2\pi\!\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\right)
                         = \frac{\pi}{3}\;}
\]

(the numerical value is about \(1.0472\ {\rm sr}\)).  

Since the dodecahedron possesses twelve equivalent faces, their solid angles add up to  

\[
12\,\Omega_{\text{pentagon}} = 12\cdot\frac{\pi}{3}=4\pi,
\]

as required for a complete surrounding solid angle.

---

### 2.   Potential at the centre

Insert \(\Omega_{\text{face}}=\pi/3\) into Eq.(1):

\[
U_{\text{center}} = V\,
        \frac{\displaystyle \frac{\pi}{3}}{4\pi}
       = V\;\frac{1}{12}.
\]

Thus the centre experiences precisely one twelfth of the voltage applied to the single active face.

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle U_{\text{centre}} = \frac{V}{12}
}
\]

assistantfinal**Step 1 – Current on the rotating shell**

For a spherical shell of radius \(R\) that carries a uniform surface‑charge density \(\sigma\) and rotates with angular speed \(\boldsymbol{\omega}= \omega\,\hat {\mathbf z}}\),

\[
\mathbf v=\boldsymbol{\omega}\times\mathbf r ,\qquad 
|\mathbf v|=\omega R\sin\theta .
\]

The surface‑current density is therefore  

\[
\boxed{\;\mathbf K =\sigma \,\mathbf v=
      \sigma \,\omega R\sin\theta \,\hat{\boldsymbol\phi}\;}
\tag{1}
\]

directed azimuthally (\(\hat{\boldsymbol\phi}\)).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**Step 2 – Magnetic dipole moment of the shell**

The magnetic dipole moment of any surface current distribution is  

\[
\mathbf m =\tfrac12\!\int_{\text{shell}} \! \mathbf r\times\mathbf K \,
            \mathrm dA .
\]

Using \(\mathbf r =R\hat{\mathbf r}\) and Eq.(1):

\[
(\mathbf r\times\mathbf K)_z
   =\sigma\omega R^{2}\sin ^2\theta ,
\]
and \(\mathrm dA =R^{2}\sin\theta\,\mathrm d\theta\,\mathrm d\varphi\).
Hence  

\[
\begin{aligned}
m_z &=\frac12\sigma\omega R^{4}
        \int_{0}^{2\pi}\!\!\mathrm d\varphi
        \int_{0}^{\pi}\!\!\sin^{3}\theta\,\mathrm d\theta \\[2mm]
    &=\frac12\sigma\omega R^{4}(2\pi)\Bigl[\frac43\Bigr]
     =\frac{4\pi}{3}\,\sigma\omega R^{4}.
\end{aligned}
\]

With the total charge \(Q=4\pi R^{2}\sigma\),

\[
\boxed{\;\mathbf m =\frac13\,Q\,\omega R^{2}\,\hat{\mathbf z}}
       =\frac{4\pi}{3}\sigma\omega R^{4}\,\hat{\mathbf z}. \tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**Step 3 – Uniform magnetic field inside the shell**

A spherical shell whose exterior field is that of a pure dipole possesses a **uniform**
internal magnetic induction,

\[
\mathbf B_{\rm int}= \frac{2}{3}\,\mu_{0}\,\mathbf M ,
\]

where the “magnetisation’’ \(\mathbf M\) satisfies  
\(\displaystyle \mathbf m =\frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}\mathbf M\).
From (2),

\[
\mathbf M =\frac{\mathbf m}{\frac{4\pi}{3}R^{3}}
          =\sigma\omega R\,\hat{\mathbf z},
\]

so that  

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbf B_{\rm int}= \frac{2}{3}\,\mu_{0}\,\sigma\omega R\,
                    \hat{\mathbf z}\;} . \tag{3}
\]

Both hemispheres experience exactly this field throughout their volume.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**Step 4 – Maxwell–stress on the equatorial cut**

To obtain the mechanical pull between the two halves we imagine cutting the sphere
by the equatorial plane (\(z=0\)).
The net force exerted on the upper hemisphere by the lower one follows from the
Maxwell stress tensor  

\[
T_{ij}= \frac{1}{\mu_{0}}\!
         \left(B_iB_j-\frac12\delta_{ij}B^{2}\right),
\]

evaluated on the fictitious flat face.   
Because the field is purely axial (\(B_x=B_y=0\)),  

\[
T_{zz}= \frac{1}{\mu_{0}}\bigl(B_z^{2}-\tfrac12 B^{2}\bigr)
       =\frac{B^{2}}{2\mu_{0}},
\]

which acts as a **pressure** compressing the two parts together.

The attractive force is this pressure multiplied by the area of the circular
cut (\(\pi R^{2}\)) :

\[
F = \frac{B^{2}}{2\mu_{0}}\;\pi R^{2}.
\]

Inserting (3),

\[
\begin{aligned}
B^{2}&=\Bigl(\frac{2}{3}\mu_{0}\sigma\omega R\Bigr)^{2}
      =\frac{4}{9}\,\mu_{0}^{2}\sigma^{2}\omega^{2}R^{2},\\[2mm]
F&= \frac{1}{2\mu_{0}}\,
    \frac{4}{9}\mu_{0}^{2}\sigma^{2}\omega^{2}R^{2}\,
    \pi R^{2}\\[2mm]
  &=\frac{2\pi}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,\sigma^{2}\,\omega^{2}\,R^{4}.
\end{aligned}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Final result

\[
\boxed{
F_{\text{north–south}} \;=\;
\frac{2\pi}{9}\,\mu_{0}\,\sigma^{2}\,\omega^{2}\,R^{4}
}
\]

This is the magnetic attraction force that pulls the northern and southern
hemispheres of a uniformly charged, steadily rotating spherical shell together.

### (a) Electric field produced by an arbitrary charge density \( \rho (\mathbf r')\)

\[

\[

\boldsymbol\nabla\phi(\mathbf r)

field is **irrotational** :

\[
\boldsymbol\nabla\times\mathbf E(\mathbf r)=\mathbf 0 ,
\]

so a scalar potential exists everywhere (up to an additive constant).
It is precisely Eq.( 2 ); explicitly,

\[

\]

Taking the divergence of (3) or, equivalently, applying the Laplacian to

\[

\[

\\[4pt]

\end{aligned}}
\tag{6}
\]

Thus the electric field inside the guide is given either by (4) (TE family) or by (5) together

##### Dispersion relation  

From (3) we finally obtain the **dispersion law**

\[

\beta^{2}=k_{0}^{2}-\Bigl(\frac{m\pi}{a}\Bigr)^{2}
                -\Bigl(\frac{n\pi}{b}\Bigr)^{2}

Define the **phase velocity** along the guide axis

\[

\qquad

 }v_{g}\equiv\frac{{\rm d}\omega}{{\rm d}\beta}.

\[

\[

metallic waveguide.

\]

*Polar‑angle derivative*

\[
\frac{\partial V}{\partial\theta}
=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\;p\,
        \frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}\theta}\bigl(\cos\theta\bigr)\,
        r^{-2}
=-\frac{p\sin\theta}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,r^{2}} .
\]

Therefore

-\frac{2p\cos\theta}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,r^{3}}\;\hat{\mathbf r}

\]

Because \({\bf E}= -\nabla V\),

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle 
\mathbf E(r,\theta)=
\frac{p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
\frac{1}{r^{3}}
\Bigl(
2\cos\theta\,\hat{\mathbf r}
+\sin\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}
\Bigr)} .
\tag{2}
\]

A point charge \(q\) feels the force  
\[
\mathbf F=q\mathbf E
     =q\frac{p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
       \frac{1}{r^{3}}
       \Bigl(
         2\cos\theta\,\hat{\mathbf r}
        +\sin\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}
       \Bigr).\tag{3}
\]

---

#### 1.  Lagrangian description  

Using spherical coordinates \((r,\theta ,\phi )\) the kinetic energy is  

\[
T=\frac{m}{2}\Bigl(\dot r^{2}+r^{2}\dot\theta ^{2}
                 +r^{2}\sin ^{2}\!\theta \,\dot\phi ^{2}\Bigr),
\]

while the electrostatic potential energy is  

\[
U(q,r,\theta)=qV
            =\frac{q p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
              \frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}} .
\]

Consequently the Lagrangian reads  

\[
L=T-U=
\frac{m}{2}\Bigl(\dot r^{2}+r^{2}\dot\theta ^{2}
                +r^{2}\sin ^{2}\!\theta \,\dot\phi ^{2}\Bigr)
-
\frac{q p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
\frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}}.\tag{4}
\]

Because the system possesses azimuthal symmetry, the generalized
coordinate \(\phi\) does **not** appear in \(L\);
its conjugate momentum therefore conserves:

\[
p_{\phi}= \frac{\partial L}{\partial\dot\phi}
        =mr^{2}\sin ^{2}\!\theta \,\dot\phi =\hbox{const}.
\]

The charge starts from rest on the \(x y\)‑plane,
so initially \(\dot\phi =0\); hence \(p_{\phi}=0\) and consequently  

\[
\dot\phi(t)=0\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad\phi={\rm const}.
\]

The motion is therefore restricted to a single meridional half‑plane
containing the origin (the “vertical” plane shown below).  

---

#### 2.  Elimination of the radial degree of freedom  

At the instant of release the particle sits at \(\theta=\pi/2\) and
has zero kinetic energy, whence the total mechanical energy equals the
potential value at that point:

\[
E = T+U =0 ,
\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad
\frac{m}{2}\bigl(\dot r^{2}+r^{2}\dot\theta ^{2}\bigr)
           =\frac{-q p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
             \frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}} .
\tag{5}
\]

(The right‑hand side is non‑negative because during the subsequent
motion \(\cos\theta\le 0\); the charge is attracted toward the region
where \(\theta>\pi/2\).)

Introduce the auxiliary variable  

\[
u(\theta)=\frac{{\rm d}r}{{\rm d}\theta}
        =\frac{\dot r}{\dot\theta },
\]

which allows us to rewrite Eq.(5) as  

\[
\frac{m}{2}\bigl(u^{2}+r^{2}\bigr)\dot\theta ^{2}
   =\frac{-q p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
     \frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}} .
\tag{6}
\]

Solving (6) for \(\dot\theta ^{2}\) and substituting the result into the
Euler–Lagrange equation for \(\theta\),

\[
\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}t}\!
\Bigl(mr^{2}\dot\theta\Bigr)
   -\frac{q p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
    \frac{\sin\theta}{r^{2}}=0,
\tag{7}
\]

eliminates the explicit appearance of \(\dot r\) and leaves a closed
equation for \(\theta(t)\):

\[
\boxed{\;
\ddot\theta+
\omega^{2}\sin\theta =0,
\qquad
\omega^{2}\equiv
\frac{|q|p}{4\pi\varepsilon _0 m\,a^{3}}\;}
\tag{8}
\]

where \(a\equiv r(t=0)\) is the initial distance from the origin.
Equation (8) is precisely the nonlinear pendulum equation; the
“length’’ of the equivalent pendulum is the unchanged distance
\(a\).  

---

#### 3.  Geometry of the trajectory  

Integrating (8) once gives the familiar energy integral of a simple
pendulum,

\[
\frac12 a^{2}\dot\theta^{2}+ \omega^{2}a^{2}\,(1-\cos\theta)=\mathrm{constant},
\]

whose solution describes a motion bounded between two symmetric values
of \(\theta\): \(\theta_{\max}= \pi/2\) (release point) and
\(\theta_{\min}= \pi/2-\Delta\theta\).   
During the whole cycle the radial coordinate remains exactly the
initial one, \(r(t)=a\); consequently the spatial path traced out by the
charge is the intersection of the vertical plane \(\phi=\textrm{const}\)
with the sphere of radius \(a\).  This intersection is a **great
circle**, i.e. a perfect semicircular arc whose centre coincides with the
origin.

Thus a charge released from rest anywhere on the \(x y\)‑plane executes
oscillatory motion exactly like a frictionless pendulum suspended at the
origin, sweeping back and forth through a semicircle of radius equal to

\frac{2z^{2}-r^{2}}{(z^{2}+r^{2})^{5/2}}\!.
\]

Because the dipole translates with speed \(v\),

\[
\varepsilon(z)= -\frac{{\rm d}\Phi}{{\rm d}t}=v\frac{{\rm d}\Phi}{{\rm d}z}
=-\frac{3\mu_0\mu v\,z}{2R^{3}}
\left[1+\Bigl(\frac{z}{R}\Bigr)^{2}\right]^{-5/2}.
\]

With a thin‑wall (\(t\!\ll\!R\)), the azimuthal electric field is  
\(E_\varphi=\varepsilon/(2\pi R)\) and the surface current density is  

\[
K_\varphi(z)=\sigma t\,E_\varphi
=-\frac{3\mu_0\mu\sigma tv\,z}{4\pi R^{4}}
\left[1+\Bigl(\frac{z}{R}\Bigr)^{2}\right]^{-5/2}.
\]

The resistive power dissipated in the wall is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}
\frac{K_\varphi^{2}}{\sigma t}\,(2\pi R)\,dz\\[2mm]
&=\frac{9\mu_0^{2}\mu^{2}\sigma t v^{2}}{8\pi R^{7}}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}z^{2}\!
\left[1+\Bigl(\frac{z}{R}\Bigr)^{2}\right]^{-5}dz \\[2mm]
&=\frac{9\mu_0^{2}\mu^{2}\sigma t v^{2}}{8\pi R^{7}}\;
R^{3}\!\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}x^{2}(1+x^{2})^{-5}dx\\[2mm]
&=\frac{9\mu_0^{2}\mu^{2}\sigma t v^{2}}{8\pi R^{4}}\;\frac{5\pi}{128}\\[2mm]
&=\frac{45}{1024}\,
\frac{\mu_0^{2}\mu^{2}\sigma t}{R^{4}}\,v^{2}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Since the magnetic drag force obeys \(F_{\mathrm{drag}}v=P\),

\[
F_{\mathrm{drag}}=\frac{45}{1024}\,
\frac{\mu_0^{2}\mu^{2}\sigma t}{R^{4}}\,v .
\]

\(mg = F_{\mathrm{drag}}\). Solving for \(v=v_{\text{term}}\),

\[
\boxed{
v_{\text{terminal}}=
\frac{1024}{45}\,
\frac{m g\,R^{4}}{\mu_{0}^{2}\,\mu^{2}\,\sigma\,t }
}.
\]

Thus the terminal speed grows linearly with the object's weight and with the fourth power of the tube radius, while it decreases inversely with the electrical conductivity, wall thickness, and the square of the magnetic dipole moment.
